class.name: Time
class.doc:
Time represents a point in time. Why re-implementing one of this object and not using a `struct timeval` or a `std::chrono` ? We are dealing with long living experiment on heterogenous systems. Under this circunstances, we would like also to measure precise time difference. For this purpose we could use the framegrabber monolotic clock, which is timestamping every frame we acquired.
Well the issue is that we cannot solely rely on this clock, as we may have several computers each with their own monolithic clock. Or even with a single computer, every time we started the tracking we must assume a new monotonic clock.
We could use the wall clock but this clock may be resetted any time, and we would end up with issue where a time difference between two consecutive frames could be negative.
Inspired from golang [time.Time](https://golang.org/pkg/time#Time) we propose an Object that store both a Wall time, and a Monotonic timestamp. But here we could have different monotonic timestamp. We try, whenever its possible (both Time have a monotonic time, and they are issued from the same monotonic clock), use that value for time differences and comparisons. Otherwise the Wall clock value will be used with the issue regarding the jitter or Wall clock reset.
Differentiaing Monotonic clock is done through MonoclockID values. The 0 value is reserved for the SYSTEM_MONOTONIC_CLOCK and which is used by Now. When reading saved monotonic Timestamp from the filesystem (as it is the case when reading data from different `TrackingDataDirectory` ), care must be taken to assign different MonoclockID for each of those reading. This class does not enforce any mechanism. The only entry point to define the MonoclockID is through the utility function FromTimestampAndMonotonic.
Every time are considered UTC.

variable.name: SYSTEM_MONOTONIC_CLOCK
variable.doc: The fort::myrmidon::Time::MonoclockID reserved for the current system ( aka `CLOCK_MONOTONIC`).

class.name: Overflow
class.brief: Time values can overflow when performing operation on them.

typedef.name: ConstPtr
typedef.brief: A const pointer to a Time

typedef.name: SortableKey
typedef.brief: An object optimized for std::map or std::set keys
typedef.doc: SortableKey is an object constructed from current fort::myrmidon::Time::Time and fort::myrmidon::Time::Time to be used as a computationnaly efficient key in std::map or std::set. please note that this key has lost any monotonic information.

method.name: Add
method.brief: Adds a Duration to a Time
method.doc: R version: ```R newT <- t$add(fmSecond(1)) # a copy of t with one added second ```

return.doc: a new fort::myrmidon::Time distant by d from this fort::myrmidon::Time

method.name: After
method.brief: Reports if this time is after t
method.doc: R version: ```R t1$after(t2) # return TRUE if t1 > t2 ```

return.doc: `true` if this fort::myrmidon::Time is strictly after t

method.name: Before
method.brief: Reports if this time is before t
method.doc: R version: ```R t1$before(t2) # return TRUE if t1 < t2 ```

return.doc: `true` if this fort::myrmidon::Time is strictly before t

method.name: DebugString
method.brief: Builds a debug string
method.doc: This method is useful for internal debugging. Prefer the standard c++ formatting operator on <std::ostream>.

return.doc: a debug string with the complete time internal state.

method.name: Equals
method.brief: Reports if this time is the same than t
method.doc: R version: ```R t1$equals(t2) # return TRUE if t1 == t2 ```

return.doc: `true` if this fort::myrmidon::Time is the same than t

method.name: FromTimestamp
method.brief: Creates a Time from a protobuf Timestamp
method.doc: Creates a fort::myrmidon::Time from a protobuf Timestamp. The fort::myrmidon::Time will not have any monotonic clock value.

method.name: FromTimestampAndMonotonic
method.brief: Creates a Time from a protobuf Timestamp and an external Monotonic clock
method.doc: Creates a fort::myrmidon::Time from a protobuf Timestamp and an external monotonic clock. The two values should correspond to the same physical time. It is an helper function to create accurate fort::myrmidon::Time from data saved in `fort.hermes.FrameReadout` protobuf messages that saves both a Wall time value and a framegrabber timestamp for each frame. It is the caller responsability to manage monoID value for not mixing timestamp issued from different clocks. Nothing prevent you to use fort::myrmidon::Time::SYSTEM_MONOTONIC_CLOCK for the monoID value but the behavior manipulating resulting times is undefined.

return.doc: the converted fort::myrmidon::Time with associated monotonic data

argument.name: nsecs
argument.doc: the external monotonic value in nanoseconds

method.name: FromTimeT
method.brief: Creates a Time from `time_t`
method.doc: Creates a fort::myrmidon::Time from `time_t`. The fort::myrmidon::Time will not have any monotonic clock value.

method.name: FromTimeval
method.brief: Creates a Time from `struct timeval`
method.doc: Creates a fort::myrmidon::Time from `struct timeval`. The fort::myrmidon::Time will not have any monotonic clock value.

method.name: HasMono
method.brief: Reports the presence of a monotonic time value
method.doc: Reports the presence of a monotonic time value. Only fort::myrmidon::Time issued by fort::myrmidon::Time::Now or fort::myrmidon::Time::FromTimestampAndMonotonic contains a monotonic time value.

return.doc: `true` if `this` contains a monotonic clock value.

method.name: MonoFromSecNSec
method.brief: Helpers to convert (sec,nsec) to nsec
method.doc: Helpers to convert (sec,nsec) to nsec. Throws fort::myrmidon::Time::Overflow on overflow.

method.name: MonoID
method.brief: Gets the referred MonoclockID.
method.doc: Gets the referred fort::myrmidon::Time::MonoclockID. It throws <std::exception> if this fort::myrmidon::Time has no monotonic clock value (see fort::myrmidon::Time::HasMono).

return.doc: the fort::myrmidon::Time::MonoclockID designating the monotonic clock the monotonic time value refers to.

method.name: MonotonicValue
method.brief: Gets the monotonic value.
method.doc: Gets the monotonic value. It throws std::exception if this fort::myrmidon::Time has no monotonic clock value (see fort::myrmidon::Time::HasMono).

method.name: Now
method.brief: Gets the current Time
method.doc:
Gets the current fort::myrmidon::Time. This time will both have a wall and a monotonic clock reading associated with the fort::myrmidon::Time::SYSTEM_MONOTONIC_CLOCK. Therefore such idioms:
``` Time start = Time::Now(); SomeFunction(); Duration ellapsed = Time::Now().Sub(start); ```
Will always return a positive fort::myrmidon::Duration, even if the wall clock has been reset between the two calls to Now
R version: ```R t <- fmTimeNow() ```

method.name: operator<
method.brief: Less than operator

argument.name: other
argument.doc: the other fort::myrmidon::Time to compare to

method.name: operator<=
method.brief: Less or equal operator

argument.name: other
argument.doc: the other fort::myrmidon::Time to compare to

method.name: operator==
method.brief: Equal comparison operator

argument.name: other
argument.doc: the other fort::myrmidon::Time to compare to

method.name: operator>
method.brief: Greater than operator

argument.name: other
argument.doc: the other fort::myrmidon::Time to compare to

method.name: operator>=
method.brief: Greate or equal operator

argument.name: other
argument.doc: the other fort::myrmidon::Time to compare to

method.name: Parse
method.brief: Parses from RFC 3339 date string format.
method.doc:
Parses from [RFC 3339](https://www.ietf.org/rfc/rfc3339.txt) date string format, i.e. string of the form `1972-01-01T10:00:20.021-05:00`. It is merely a wrapper from google::protobuf::time_util functions.
R version: ```R t <- fmTimeParse("1972-01-01T00:00:00.000Z") ```

method.name: Round
method.brief: Rounds a Time to a Duration
method.doc:
Rounds the fort::myrmidon::Time to the halp-rounded up fort::myrmidon::Duration d. Currently only multiple of fort::myrmidon::Duration::Second and power of 10 of fort::myrmidon::Duration::Nanosecond which are smaller than a second are supported.
R version: ```R newT <- t$round(fmSecond(1)) # a copy of t rounded at the nearest second ```

return.doc: a new fort::myrmidon::Time rounded to the wanted duration

method.name: SortKey
method.brief: Builds a SortableKey for std::map and std::set.
method.doc: Builds a fort::myrmidon::Time::SortableKey representing this fort::myrmidon::Time suitable for <std::map> and <std::set>.

method.name: SortKey
method.brief: Builds a SortableKey representing a Time pointer
method.doc: Builds a fort::myrmidon::Time::SortableKey representing a fort::myrmidon::Time::ConstPtr. Passing a nullptr to this function, will represent the smallest possible key possible, which is then mathematically equivalent to -âˆž fort::myrmidon::Time (no result of fort::myrmidon::Time::Parse can represent this value).

argument.name: timePtr
argument.doc: the source fort::myrmidon::Time::ConstPtr to build a fort::myrmidon::Time::SortableKey for.

method.name: Sub
method.brief: Computes time difference with another time
method.doc: R version: ```R # gets the fmDuration between t1 and t2 t1$sub(t2) ```

return.doc: a fort::myrmidon::Duration representing the time ellapsed between `this` and t. It could be negative.

argument.name: t
argument.doc: the fort::myrmidon::Time to substract to this one.

method.name: ToTimestamp
method.brief: Converts to a protobuf Timestamp message

return.doc: the protobuf Timestamp representing the fort::myrmidon::Time.

method.name: ToTimestamp
method.brief: In-place conversion to a protobuf Timestamp

argument.name: timestamp
argument.doc: the timestamp to modify to represent the fort::myrmidon::Time

method.name: ToTimeT
method.brief: Converts to a `time_t`
method.doc: Converts to a `time_t`. Please note that time_t have a maximal resolution of a second.

method.name: ToTimeval
method.brief: Converts to a `struct timeval`
method.doc: Converts to a `struct timeval`. Please note that time_t have a maximal resolution of a microsecond.
